summary.seg: This manuscript, completed in 1654, is a Leitourgikon, which contains those portions of the text for the main eucharistic liturgy that are read by the priest. It includes the three versions of the liturgy in general Greek Orthodox use: the Liturgy of St John Chrysostom, the Liturgy of St Basil, and the Liturgy of the Presanctified Gifts. The latter is used during Lent, in which period the bread and wine of Communion are consecrated before the service; consequently, the consecration is not included in the text. Each of the three liturgies here is preceded by a diataxis, a prefatory text giving further instructions to the priest. The manuscript also contains the Office of the Lesser Purification, the standard rite for the blessing of holy water. It is richly ornamented with headpieces preceding the texts and many large and elaborate initial letters.

The text is written in a number of different styles of script, but appears to be the work of a single scribe, switching between styles in order to distinguish the different portions of the text. The first and last items of text, the diataxis to the liturgy of St John Chrysostom and the Office of the Lesser Purification (ff. i recto-i verso, ii recto-iv verso) are written in particularly small script, unparalleled elsewhere in the manuscript, and it has been suggested that they were the work of a later hand. In this case, these texts would have to have been added on originally blank endleaves, since these folios belong to the main quire structure and are not distinct additions. This question is particularly significant as the copyist of these portions included a colophon (on f. iv verso), giving his name as Dionysios and the year in which he completed his work as 1654. The dating of the bulk of the manuscript and identification of its copyist therefore depends on whether this was the same person responsible for the first and last items.

However, the style of the hand and ornament of the small script seems consistent with those appearing elsewhere in the manuscript, while the watermarks of the papers used in the manuscript suggest a date for its production of around 1650, very close to the date given in the colophon. It would also be peculiar if the diataxis of the liturgy appearing first had not been included by the original scribe, as those given for the other two liturgies refer back to it. It remains possible that the former was included as an afterthought, after the copying of the manuscript had begun but before the copying of the Liturgy of St Basil began, but it seems very likely that the full content of the manuscript belongs to the same programme of work by Dionysios.

msItem.title: Diataxis for the liturgy of St John Chrysostom
msItem.incipit: f. i recto Τῶν ἁγίων καὶ θαυματουργῶν ἀναργύρων Κοσμᾶ καὶ Δαμιανοῦ· κύρου καὶ Ἰωάννου· Παντελεήμονος καὶ Ἐρμολάου
msItem.explicit: f. i verso ευχη τῆς προθεσεως

msItem.title: Liturgy of St John Chrysostom
msItem.rubric: f. 1v Η θεια λειτουγεια Ιωαννου του Χρυσόστομου
msItem.incipit: f. 1v Ὁ Θεὸς ὁ Θεὸς ἡμῶν ὁ τὸν οὐράνιον ἄρτον· τὴν τροφὴν τοῦ παντὸς κόσμου
msItem.explicit: f. 36r ὁ δὲ λαὸς κλίνοντες τὰς κεφαλᾶς λέγουσιν τὸ δι εὐχῶν: καὶ ἁπὲρχονται ἐν ειρήνῃ συν Θεῶ
msItem.finalRubric: f. 36r Τέλος τῆς λειτουργείας τοῦ Χρυσοστὸμου
msItem.note: Ed. J. Goar, Euchologion, 2nd edition (Venice 1730), chapter 3, sections 1-19 (pp. 51-70)
The words forming the end of a section on f. 13r incorporate symbols not belonging to the Greek alphabet, standing for letters and a mark following the end of words
f. 1r is blank; f. 36v is blank apart from later notes

msItem.title: Diataxis for the Liturgy of St Basil
msItem.rubric: f. 37r Η θεια λειτουργια του εν αγιοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Βασιλειου του μεγαλου
msItem.incipit: f. 37r Γίνωσκε ὅτι ἐτούτη ἡ λειτουργία· δέκα φοραῖς τὸν χρόνον λέγεται
msItem.explicit: f. 37r καὶ διὰ ταὔτὸ ἐρμηνίαις δὲν γράφωμεν

msItem.title: Liturgy of St Basil
msItem.incipit: f. 37v Ὁ Θεὸς ὁ Θεὸς ἡμῶν, ὁ τὸν οὐρανιον ἄρτον, τὴν τροφὴν τοῦ παντὸς κόσμου
msItem.explicit: f. 69r Ὥφθης βάσις ἄσειστος τῆ ἐκκλησία νὲμων πᾶσιν ἄσυλον τὴν κυριὁτητα βροτοὶς ἐπισφαγίζων σοὶς δόγμασι οὑρανοφάντορ Βασίλειε ὅσιε
msItem.finalRubric: f. 69r Τέλος τῆς λειτουργίας τοῦ ἐν ἁγίοις πατρὸς ἡμῶν Βασιλείου ἀρχιεπισκόπου Καισαρείας καὶ Καππαδοκίας οὐρανοφάντορος του μεγάλου
msItem.note: Ed. J. Goar, Euchologion, 2nd edition (Venice 1730), chapter 5, sections 1-17 (pp. 135-152)

msItem.title: Diataxis for the Liturgy of the Presanctified
msItem.rubric: f. 69v Ἡ θεια λειτουργια των προ ἡγιασμενων
msItem.incipit: f. 69v Αὕτη ἡ θεία λειτουργία λέγεται εν ταῖς τεσσαρακοσταῖς νηστικαις ἡμεραὶς μόνον

msItem.title: Liturgy of the Presanctified
msItem.incipit: f. 70r Εὐλογημένη ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ Πατρὸς καὶ τοῦ Υἱοῦ καὶ τοῦ Ἁγίου Πνεύματος
msItem.explicit: f. 83r σύναψον ἡμᾶς τῇ λογικῆ σου ποίμνῃ καὶ κληρονόμους ἀνάδειξον τῆς βασιλείας σου, νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων
msItem.note: Ed. J. Goar, Euchologion, 2nd edition (Venice 1730), chapter 7, section 3 (pp. 162-168)

The end of the text on f. 83r is followed by a word written in symbols not from the Greek alphabet; in such a context the word ἀμήν or τέλος would be expected; by analogy to the use of some of these symbols, integrated into Greek text, on f. 13r, it can be conjectured that this represents τέλος
f. 83v is blank apart from some later notes

msItem.title: Office of the Lesser Purification
msItem.rubric: f. ii recto Ακολουθία τοῦ μικροῦ αγιασμοῦ
msItem.incipit: f. ii recto Ποιει ὁ ιερεὺς ευλογητὸν τὸ Κύριε εισακουσον
msItem.explicit: f. iv verso δέσποτα πολυἑλεε η Χριστὸς ὁ ἀληθινὸς
msItem.note: Ed. J. Goar, Euchologion, 2nd edition (Venice 1730), chapter 19, sections 1-4 (pp. 358-362)

msItem.colophon: Η χὴρ μεν ἡ γράψασα ταῦτον τῶν βίων σαπησεται φεὺ, καὶ γενἥσεται μόνης ἡ δε γραφὴ μένουσα εἰς αἰὤνας Τέλος ͵αχνδʹ ὁ γράψας Διονύσιος

support.material: ff. 1-2, 7-16 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Crescent ( c. 70 c. 30 ) in the gutter, similar to Velkov 12-15. These examples are dated to 1658-1661.
ff. 3-6, 17-79 Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Crown ( c. 75 52 ) in the gutter.
ff. 80-83, ii-iv Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermark: Anchor ( c. 60 45 ) in the gutter, comparable but not identical to Velkov 237-239, 249, 289, 292. These examples are dated to 1638-1650.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers [a] + i, 1-83, ii-iv + [b], in pencil, in Arabic and Roman numerals, recto, upper right.

collation.p: The manuscript consists of 11 quires, all quaternia. The signatures suggest that another folio has been lost at the beginning.

list.item: Quire 18+1 ff. i, 1-8 An additional folio has been adhered to the beginning of the quire.
Quire 38-1 ff. 17-23 The last folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 118-1 ff. 80-83, ii-iv The last folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are quire signatures in Greek numerals on the first folio of each quire, in black ink, recto, lower centre. Some have been lost to cropping. They survive in whole or in part on Quires 6, 8, 10 (ζʹ, θʹ, ιαʹ), with traces on Quires 4, 7.

supportDesc.condition: f. 80 is partially detached. There are small losses from the edges of some folios (e.g. ff. 5, 33 and 51). Tears to ff. 5-6 and iv have been repaired with Japanese paper. There is slight creasing, some water staining, drops of wax and areas of dirt.

layoutDesc.layout: ff. i recto-i verso, ii recto-iv verso A single column of 43-44 lines. 142-148 85-90
f. 1r-83v A single column of 18 lines. 140 90

handNote.p: The manuscript was apparently copied by a single hand in multiple styles and sizes of mixed minuscule script, in black and red ink. The predominant style of the main text is derivative of the Hodegon style, using many elaborate ligatures.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is subscript or absent. There is occasional decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, middle comma, question mark and full stop.
The heading to each liturgy is in epigraphic display majuscule. Those on ff. 37r and 69v are written in red ink; the one on f. 1v is painted in various colours.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of each liturgy, and that of the Office of the Lesser Purification, is preceded by a headpiece outlined in black or red ink, with red, blue, green, yellow and golden paint infill. The one on f. 1v is a large rectangular vegetative design similar to many of the major initials, that on f. 37r is a rectangular design composed of a loose interlaced grid with vegetative protrusions, that on f. 69v is a slender plait, and that on f. ii recto is a larger, rectangular plaited interlace design.

The text of each liturgy, and that of many sections within them, begins with a major initial, usually outlined in black ink, with dark red, blue, green, yellow and golden paint infill. These are vegetative in style and some also incorporate zoomorphic forms (e.g. ff. 62v, 78v) or hands giving a blessing or grasping other parts of the design (e.g. ff. 42v, 81v). A few follow a different style, such as that on f. 80v, outlined in black ink with yellow and bright red paint infill, or that on f. 68r, in red and black ink.
The beginnings of other sections are marked by minor initials in red ink, of varying sizes and degrees of elaboration.

physDesc.additions: There are occasional marginal annotations in Greek and manicules added by various later hands (e.g. ff. f. 14r, f. 43v, 73v, 83r). Brief prayers and other notes have been written on the originally blank ff. 36v and 83v, by a crude hand with poor spelling. These include, on 83v, the names of the priests Paulos and Demetrios: Παυλου ἱερεως Δὴμητρὴου ἱερεως.

binding.p: 17th-century full leather binding over millboards, with supported sewing on cord and separate sewn endleaves. Both boards are decorated with blind tooling, including large stamps with figurative and non-figurative designs. These designs include a lion and unicorn fighting under two crowns, two beasts fighting in the air over a city, and a seal, now heavily worn, with its inscription illegible and central image lost.

accMat.p: On the left pastedown are a bookplate of T. S. Blakeney and another of the Fitzwilliam Museum recording the manuscript's donation by Blakeney in 1955.

A note is attached to f. [a] recto, concerning the content, date and script of the manuscript and comparisons with others at the British Museum, based on remarks by T. C. (Theodore Cressy) Skeat (1907-2003) Skeat, T. C. (Theodore Cressy) , Keeper of Manuscripts at the British Museum 1961-1972.

history.origin: The manuscript was copied by one Dionysios Dionysios and completed in 1654.
history.provenance: Owned by Thomas S. Blakeney Blakeney, T. S. (Thomas S.) .
history.acquisition: Presented to the Fitzwilliam Museum by Blakeney, 20 January 1955.

availability.p: Visitors to the Fitzwilliam Museum who wish to consult Collection material are required to apply to the Museum in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Fitzwilliam Museum: Study Room.

analytic.title: Greek manuscripts in Cambridge: recent acquisitions by college libraries, the Fitzwilliam Museum and private collectors.
